We are running 5 instances of Heritrix and passing the diverted files 
between each instance.  If we are planning on collecting 1 billion total 
pages (+ images and documents ). Is it reasonable to stop passing 
diverted files after some point in the crawl?

We currently have collected 120 million pages (300 million URIs) on each 
instance (total of 600 M pages, 1.5 billion URIs), and we have over 600 
million URIs queued on each instance (total of 3 billion URIs).  When we 
pass more diverted files, it seems that many of these URIs will never be 
crawled.  Can someone explain how this would/could change the course of 
the crawl if we would stop passing the diverted files at this point? 
What are the benefits, if any of doing one over the other?

Can anyone talk about the effect of how the decision to pass diverted 
files has on a crawl over not passing them can change the results of a 
crawl?

Thank you,

--David
